abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Biallelic hypomorphic variants in <jats:italic>PRORP</jats:italic> have been recently described as causing the autosomal recessive disorder combined oxidative phosphorylation deficiency type 54 (COXPD54). COXPD54 encompasses a phenotypic spectrum of sensorineural hearing loss and ovarian insufficiency (Perrault syndrome) to leukodystrophy. Here, we report three additional families with homozygous missense <jats:italic>PRORP</jats:italic> variants with pleiotropic phenotypes. Each missense variant altered a highly conserved residue within the metallonuclease domain. In vitro mitochondrial tRNA processing assays with recombinant TRMT10C, SDR5C1 and PRORP indicated two COXPD54-associated <jats:italic>PRORP</jats:italic> variants, c.1159A>G (p.Thr387Ala) and c.1241C>T (p.Ala414Val), decreased pre-tRNA<jats:sup>Ile</jats:sup> cleavage, consistent with both variants impacting tRNA processing. No significant decrease in tRNA processing was observed with <jats:italic>PRORP</jats:italic> c.1093T>C (p.Tyr365His), which was identified in an individual with leukodystrophy. These data provide independent evidence that <jats:italic>PRORP</jats:italic> variants are associated with COXPD54 and that the assessment of 5′ leader mitochondrial tRNA processing is a valuable assay for the functional analysis and clinical interpretation of novel <jats:italic>PRORP</jats:italic> variants.</jats:p>
